data.name: ZY\sEncode
data.description:
# I bring to your attention a kata called ZY\sEncode.

Here was supposed to be a motivating story about spies and bandits, but for another time.

So, to the point.

Before you, in fact, the cipher.
Encryption example:

```javascript
'hello world!' => 'c0gzb gozdd azdkl zekpy fm1zd s4zes gzdkl zc0gz 1i4'
```

In order not to turn an interesting kata into a boring torture, here are some research tips for you:
- you don't need to go deep into bits
- you don't need any "key" to decrypt
- the encryption method used is... lol jk im not telling you
- think of a Unicode table
- carefully selected test cases
- read the title again

I think that's enough for a start.

## NOTE
If you're stuck, here are some more tips. Open them one by one and keep trying!
So that you don’t read them by accident, I encrypted them using the incredibly complex ROT13 algorithm, about which you can’t find information anywhere on the Internet and, moreover, an online decryption service.

Even `rot13.com` will not help

So the list is:
- frevbhfyl, guvax nobhg gur Havpbqr gnoyr. Tbbtyr n enatr bs Ratyvfu yrggref.
- qb lbh frr ng yrnfg bar pncvgny yrggre va gur pvcure? Jul qb lbh guvax?
- bxnl, abj vg'f abg n uvag, ohg n xvpx va gur evtug qverpgvba. Ahzoref ner abg bayl ovanel, qrpvzny naq urknqrpvzny.
- frevbhfyl? Zber crefrirenapr!
- bx, ohg guvf vf gur ynfg pyhr. Gur tncf ner qrpbengvir.
- v gbyq lbh gur ynfg pyhr unf nyernql orra tvira. Tbbq yhpx!

---
Good luck!
